body_html:
The .whl file provided by @fo40225 solved this issue for me.

OS Name Microsoft Windows 10 Pro
Processor Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-3570K CPU @ 3.40GHz, 3401 Mhz, 4 Core(s), 4 Logical Processor(s)
System Type x64-based PC

Here is a list of CPU's compatible with AVX instructions used in version 1.6 of tensorflow.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions#CPUs_with_AVX

EDIT: It does seem like my Intel Core i5-3570K has support for AVX which makes me a bit suspicious whether or not my issue actually is fixed.

When I validate the installation everything works, so I guess that's it! :)
Although I get a warning when doing the installation validation recommended by tensorflow. ( https://www.tensorflow.org/install/install_windows )
`

import tensorflow as tf
hello = tf.constant('hello, Tensorflow!')
sess = tf.Session()
2018-03-04 13:32:15.912873: I C:\Users\User\Source\Repos\tensorflow\tensorflow\core\platform\cpu_feature_guard.cc:140] Your CPU supports instructions that this TensorFlow binary was not compiled to use: AVX
print(sess.run(hello))
b'hello, Tensorflow!'

EDIT2: Btw, I'm using CUDA 9.1 which apparently isn't recommended with tensorflow 1.6.`But I think the .whl file @fo40225 provided allows for the latest version of CUDA in constrast to the tensorflow pip package.

EDIT2: Btw, I'm using CUDA 9.1 which apparently isn't recommended with tensorflow 1.6.`But I think the .whl file @fo40225 provided allows for the latest version of CUDA in constrast to the tensorflow pip package.
body:
The .whl file provided by @fo40225 solved this issue for me. 

OS Name	Microsoft Windows 10 Pro
Processor	Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-3570K CPU @ 3.40GHz, 3401 Mhz, 4 Core(s), 4 Logical Processor(s)
System Type	x64-based PC

Here is a list of CPU's compatible with AVX instructions used in version 1.6 of tensorflow. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions#CPUs_with_AVX 

EDIT: It does seem like my Intel Core i5-3570K has support for AVX which makes me a bit suspicious whether or not my issue actually is fixed. 

When I validate the installation everything works, so I guess that's it! :) 
Although I get a warning when doing the installation validation recommended by tensorflow. ( https://www.tensorflow.org/install/install_windows )
`
>>> import tensorflow as tf
>>> hello = tf.constant('hello, Tensorflow!')
>>> sess = tf.Session()
2018-03-04 13:32:15.912873: I C:\Users\User\Source\Repos\tensorflow\tensorflow\core\platform\cpu_feature_guard.cc:140] Your CPU supports instructions that this TensorFlow binary was not compiled to use: AVX
>>> print(sess.run(hello))
b'hello, Tensorflow!'
>>>


EDIT2: Btw, I'm using CUDA 9.1 which apparently isn't recommended with tensorflow 1.6.`But I think the .whl file @fo40225 provided allows for the latest version of CUDA in constrast to the tensorflow pip package.
